messageBody:
On 7/27/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
> Hi CÃ©dric,
>
> It is more tedious to use a reader since you have to remeber that you
> should close it and decide who closes it (I assume readLines takes
> care of that in the file example). If you don't close it you can leak
> resources.
>

I liked the Reader one best actually. It would be even better if
BufferedReader implemented Iterable<String> so you could do

for(String line : new BufferedReader(input)) {
processLine(line);
}

As for closing the stream/reader - that should always be the
responsibility of the person who opened it. I fantasize about
something like a Ruby closure

new File("x.txt").read(fileprocessor)

(where read() does the opening and closing) but I am not exactly sure
how that would work in Java without a mass of ugly interfaces and
callbacks.

Maybe if there was something called Readable and a Reader was
something that could read Readables...?

interface Reader {
void read(Readable in);
}

class MyProcessor implements Readable {}

new FileReadable("x.txt").read(myprocessor);

Something like C#'s /using/ keyword to close Closeables would not suck.

Kevin
